[16]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[17]  A grammatical shift from plural to singular.

[18]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[19]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[20]  Literally ‘protect yourselves against a day’.

[21]  A grammatical shift describing past events in present tense, serving to create a vivid portrait of events.

[22]Q   Abu ʻAmr, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . appointed for Moses . . .”

[23]  By mortifying it.

[24]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “Your offenses will be forgiven for you . . .”

[25]  A grammatical shift from 2nd person to 3rd person.

[26]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[27]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[28]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and no fear shall ever be upon them nor shall they grieve.”

[29]Q   Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . of what they do.”

[30]  The Jews.

[31]  A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

[32]Q   Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . whose offenses have surrounded . . .”

[33]Q   Ibn Kathir, Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “They shall worship . . .”

[34]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[35]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[36]  A grammatical shift from 3rd person to 2nd person.

[37]Q   All except for Nafieʻ, ʻAsem, Al-Kesa’i, Yaʻqub and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . you ransom them,”

[38]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Shuʻbah, Yaʻqub and Khalaf in his preferred narration read it as: “. . . what they do.”

[39]  A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense; using present tense for an old practice emphasizes that it was a tradition frequently practiced.

[40]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . what Allah has sent down . . .”

[41]  Using present tense for an old practice emphasizes that it was a tradition frequently practiced.

[42]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . of what youpl do.”

[43]  This sentence is left open-ended; according to Ibn ʻAshour and other exegetes, its predicate is “then let him take God as an enemy.”

[44]  A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense; using present tense for an old practice emphasizes that it was a tradition frequently practiced.

[45]  Blaspheme.

[46]  Sorcery.

[47]  This word means ‘Pay heed to us’ but sounds similar to a Hebrew word that means ‘the most evil of us’.

[48]  Grant us consideration.

[49]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . be bestowed upon you from on high by yourpl Lord.”

[50]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “Never do we command the abrogation of any . . .”

[51]  The Arabic word used is ayah.  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[52]Q   Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . nor postpone it unless We . . .”

[53]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[54]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[55]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and no fear shall ever be upon them nor shall they grieve.”

[56]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[57]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “They said . . .”

[58]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “He only says to it, ‘Be,’ so it is.”

[59]Q   Nafieʻ and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . as a warner, so do not ask about the fellows of purgatory.”

[60]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[61]  Literally ‘protect yourselves against a day’.

[62]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[63]Q   Nafieʻ and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “And they took from Abraham’s . . .”

[64]  The Arabic word used is Muslimayn, the dual form of Muslimeen which means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

[65]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[66]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[67]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “And with this Abraham enjoined . . .”

[68] The Arabic word used is Muslimoon which means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

[69]Q   Nafieʻ, Abu Jaʻfar, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba and Rouh read it as: “Or do they say . . .”

[70]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[71]  The sons of Jacob.

[72]  It means ‘your prayers performed towards the former direction’.

[73]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[74]Q   Ibn ʻAmer, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Rouh read it as: “. . . of what youpl do.”

[75]  A grammatical shift from 2nd person to 3rd person.

[76]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . towards which he is turned.”

[77]Q   Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . of what they do.”

[78]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[79]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[80]  Hajj.

[81]  Umrah.

[82]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “wind”.

[83]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[84]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “And if only yousg could see those who have done injustice . . .”

[85]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . when they are made to see the punishment . . .”

[86]Q   Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . could see, when they see the punishment: indeed all power belongs to Allah and indeed Allah is . . .”

[87]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[88]  A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense.

[89]  A shepherd.

[90]  A grammatical shift from 1st person to 3rd person.

[91]  Literally ‘necks’.

[92]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[93]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[94]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[95]  The will.

[96]  This sign was revealed at a time when fasting was not yet obligatory, then it was abrogated by sign 185.

[97]Q   Hisham read it as: “a compensation (is allowed instead)—food for destitute people.”

  Nafieʻ, Ibn Zekwan and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . a compensation of food for destitute persons (is allowed instead.)”

[98]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[99]  Literally ‘a group’.

[100]  Hajj.

[101]  Before Islam, Arabs used to enter their houses through the backyards once they had donned their Hajj garments, thinking that entering through the door would invalidate their state of consecration for pilgrimage.

[102]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “But do not kill them at the Inviolable Mosque unless they kill you about it. So if they kill youpl, then kill them.”

[103]  Hajj.

[104]  Umrah.

[105]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[106]  Lives outside Makkah.

[107]Q   Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . then there shall be no intercourse nor ungodliness nor disputation during the Pilgrimage.”

 Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . then there shall be no intercourse nor ungodliness, and no disputation, ever, during the Pilgrimage.”

[108]  A grammatical shift from 3rd person to 1st person.

[109]  During Pilgrimage.

[110]  Through commerce.

[111]  In the valley of Mena.

[112]Q   Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . in shades of mists and angels?”

[113]  A grammatical shift from present tense to past tense.

[114]  All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, ʻAsem and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . all things return.”

[115]Q   Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . so that it may be judged between mankind . . .”

[116]  The Scripture.

[117]  Literally ‘by His leave’.

[118]Q   Nafieʻ read it as: “. . . and they were shaken as with an earthquake, such that the Messenger and those . . .”

[119]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[120]Q   Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “There is much sin in them . . .”

[121]  Literally ‘their sin’.

[122]Q   Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . until they are cleansed.”

[123]  ‘Them’ is feminine, denoting that the discourse is addressing men regarding their wives.

[124]  A grammatical shift from 2nd person to 3rd person.

[125]Q   Hamza, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . unless it is feared that they both may not maintain . . .”

[126]  Literally ‘ransoms herself’.

[127]  The latter.

[128]  She and the first husband.

[129]  The waiting period.

[130]  Literally ‘two rounds’.

[131]  The mothers.

[132]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “No mother is (supposed to be) harmed on account of her child . . .”

[133]  A grammatical shift from 3rd person to 2nd person.

[134]Q   Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . what youpl have come up with . . .”

[135]  The pronoun is plural feminine, denoting that it means ‘the widows’.

[136]  Literally ‘mention them’.

[137]  In sexual intercourse.

[138]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . before having touched each other  . . .”

[139]  Dowry.

[140]Q   All except Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs and Hamza read it as: “. . . and leave spouses behind—a bequest (is ordained upon them) for their spouses with compensation . . .”

[141]Q   All except for ʻAsem, Ibn ʻAmer and Yaʻqub read it as: “Who is it that will lend Allah a good loan (so) that He may multiply it for him manifold? For Allah withholds and extends . . .”  

[142]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . youpl return.”

[143]  Saul.

[144]  Of the covenant.

[145]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . scoops up a (single) scoop with his hand.”

[146]  Goliath.

[147]Q   Nafieʻ, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “And were it not for Allah strongly repelling some people . . .”

[148]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[149]  A grammatical shift from 3rd person to 1st person.

[150]  Literally ‘His seat’.

[151]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[152]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr,   Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . how We revivify them,”

[153]Q   Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “So when it became evident to him, He said, “Know that . . .”

[154]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[155]  According to Ibn ʻAbbas and other exegetes, ‘bend them’ is a metaphor for ‘cut them’.

[156]  Of their generosity.

[157]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and no fear shall ever be upon them nor shall they grieve.”

[158]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[159]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and whoever He brings wisdom, then he has most surely been brought much good.

[160]Q   Nafieʻ, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “. . . then that is better for you, and We will (also) remit your evil deeds for you.”

 Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba and Yaʻqub read it as: “then that is better for you. And We will remit your evil deeds for you.”

[161]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and no fear shall ever be upon them nor shall they grieve.”

[162]  On the Day of Resurrection.

[163]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[164]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[165]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[166]Q   Shuʻba and Hamza read it as: “. . . then inform (everyone) of a war . . .”

[167]  The debtor.

[168]  To waive it as charity.

[169]  Literally ‘guard yourselves against a day’.

[170]Q   Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . when you return to Allah . . .”

[171]  A grammatical shift from 2nd person to 3rd person.

[172]Q   Hamza read it as: “…so that in case one of them errs, the other reminds her.”

[173]  That is more just than oral agreements.

[182]Q   Al Kesa’i read it as: “(And) that religion with Allah is Islam.”

[183]  Literally ‘the unlettered’.

[184]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[253]  The term ‘wombs’ is usually used in the Qur’an as a metaphor for blood relatives, meaning: honor the ties of kinship.

[264]  Men were not allowed to have intimate relationships with their bondwomen who were taken captive in war—a worldwide ancient common practice—unless they menstruated at least once, to verify that they were not pregnant from their previous husbands before bondage.

[399]Q   Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “Then their saying, ‘By Allah, our Lord, we were not polytheists’ was their only turmoil.”

[412]Q   Nafieʻ and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . .  and so that yousg can realize the way of the criminals.”

[413]  The Arabic word used is yaqusu which also means ‘follows’, implying that the judgement of God follows the truth.

[649]Q   Hamza, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . . escapes yoursg Lord, nor is there anything smaller or larger but is in an evident record.”

[650]  Literally ‘scripture’.

  Rouh read it as: “So agree together about your decision, and so should your associates . . .”

[665]Q   All except for Hafs, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . to deliver the believers.”

[666]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah). Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[667]  A grammatical shift from 2nd person to 3rd person.

[668]Q   Al-Bazzi read it as: “But if youpl turn away . . .”

[669]  Literally ‘scripture’.

[672]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[673]  Each portion of the Qur’an is called a surah, which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.

[676]  This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Beqaʻi and other exegetes its predicate is: “equal to a denier?”

[1131]  Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long (see 22: 47).

[1132]Q   Hamza and Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . what He commands us?”

[1134]Q   Hamza and Khalaf read it as: “. . . wants to remember or wants to . . .”

[1135]  Humbly.

[1136]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1137]Q   All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Hafs, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . .  our offspring . . .”

[1138]Q   Shuʻba, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and will encounter therein greetings and peace . . .”

[1139]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . We can send down upon them . . .”

[1140]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “I fear that they will disbelieve me 13 and that my chest will tighten and my tongue will not be fluent . . .”

[1141]  A denier of Pharaoh’s grace.

[1142]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hisham, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . we are constantly cautious.”

[1143]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[1144]  Iblis is another name of Satan or Shaytan.

[1306]  The pronoun ‘them’ is mentioned in plural feminine form and therefore refers to the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him).

[1333]  They are either asking one another, or are being asked by the angels.

[1334]  The Arabic word used is iftah which literally means ‘open’; however, according to the dialect of the tribes of Hemyar in Yemen it means ‘judge’. Ibn Abdul-salam said that it means ‘open a way for knowledge’, in order to distinguish between good and evil, i.e. legislate for us a legislation.

[1335]  Determiner of justice.

[1336]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[1344]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

[1345]  The Arabic word used is jinn which are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

[1346]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1347]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered upon by the reader.

[1348]  In the Earlier Life of this world.

[1568]Q   All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Or do those who have perpetrated evil deeds assume that We will make them as those who have attained faith and have done righteous deeds? Equal is their life or their death; miserable is their judgment!”

[1569]Q   All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Will you not constantly remind yourselves?”

[1570]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1571]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “And yousg see every community kneeling, every community being called . . .”

[1572]Q   Hamza read it as: “And when it is said, “Indeed, the promise of Allah is true, and of the Hour there is no doubt . . .”  youpl say . . .”

[1573]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[1574]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God

[1575]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “So today they do not come out of it.”

[1576]Q   Nafieʻ, Al-Bazzi, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . .  that you may warn those . . .”

[1577]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . upon man kindness to . . .”

[1578]  The Arabic word used is Muslimeen which means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

[1579]Q   All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . from whom the best of what they have done is bound to be accepted and whose misdeeds are bound to be overlooked . . .”

[1580]  The Arabic word used is jinn which are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

[1581]Q   All except for Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr, Hisham, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and that We may render . . .”

[1582]  Prophet Hûd who was sent to the people of ʻĀd.

[1583]Q   Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . and I compile and proclaim to you . . .”

[1584]Q   All except for ʻAsem, Hamza, Yaʻqub and Khalaf read it as: “. . .  yousg could see nothing except . . .”

[1585]  Mentioned in plural form in Arabic, denoted by (s) in English for grammatical reasons.

[1586]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1587]  Literally “they strayed from them.”

[1588]  The Arabic word used is jinn which are unseen beings that are accountable for their actions.

[1589]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[1590]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . by creating them, can revive the dead?”

[1591]  i.e. Take them as captives.

[1592]Q   All except for Abu ʻAmr, Hafs and Yaʻqub read it as: “As for those who combated in the way of Allah . . .”

[1593]  Addressing Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) about the town which evicted him (Makkah).

[1594]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[1595]Q   Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . rivers of water, never staling . . .”

[1596]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural. The difference between this shift and the one in sign number 14 should be pondered by the reader.

[1597]  Each portion of the Qur’an is called a ‘surah’, which is sometimes translated as ‘chapter’.

[1598]Q   Roways read it as: “. . . in case you were made in charge, spread corruption . . .”

[1599]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and cut your family ties?

[1600]  Literally “sever your wombs”.

[1601]  Mentioned in plural form in Arabic, denoted by (s) in English for grammatical reasons.

[1602]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means recital or recitation.

[1603]Q   Abu ʻAmr read it as: “Satan has enticed them. Thus they were filled with false hopes.”

 Yaʻqub read it as: “Satan has enticed them. Thus I filled them with false hopes.”

[1604]Q   All except for Hafs, Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . their secrets.”

[1605]Q   Shuʻba read it as: “And He will certainly test youpl until He knows those of you who strive and those who are steadfastly patient, and (until He) tests your reactions.”

[1606]Q   Roways read it as: “. . . those who are steadfastly patient. And We will test your reactions.”

[1607]Q   Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . that they may believe in Allah . . .”

[1608]Q   Nafie’, Ibn Kathir, Abu Ja’far and Rouh read it as: “. . . then We will grant him a great reward.”

[1609]  The spoils of war.

[1610]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . the Words of Allah.”

[1611]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . We will enter him...We will punish him . . .”

[1612]Q   Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . what they do.”

[1613]  This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Qurtubi and other exegetes the predicate is elided but can be understood as: “I would not have prevented you from retaliating.”

[1614]  The Arabic word used is jahiliyah which is derived from jahl or ‘ignorance’ and refers to the pre-Islamic phase of paganism.

[1615]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . brings you any news, ascertain (the truth) . . .”

[1616]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . so reconcile between yourpl brothers . . .”

[1617]  The Qur’an used the term ‘yourselves’ rather than ‘each other’ to make the believers sympathize with one another by

regarding any defamation of one as defamation of all.

[1618]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[1619]Q   Ibn Kathir read it as: “. . . what they do.”

[1620]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[1621]  That which is sworn is omitted so that the reader may ponder.

[1622]  This sentence is left open-ended; according to Al-Alousi and other exegetes the predicate is elided but can be understood as: “. . . that we shall be brought back again?”

[1623]  Literally ‘scripture’.

[1624]  Two angels who receive everyone’s words and deeds during his/her life and record them.

[1625]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense, this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[1626]  Two angels: one drives the person to the place of assembly and the other is a witness to all his/her deeds.

[1627]  According to Ibn ʻAshour, some exegetes said that this comrade is an angel, and others said it is his intimate friend in life, while others said it is his devil which used to whisper to him.

[1628]Q   Nafieʻ and Shuʻba read it as: “. . . when He says to Hell . . .”

[1629]Q   Ibn Kathir read it as: “This is what they are promised . . .”

[1630]  Six equal intervals of time, which may be six heavenly days, each of them being 1000 earthly years long (see 22: 47).

[1631]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Hamza, Abu Jaʻfar and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and at the ends of prostrations.”

[1632]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . the earth vigorously ruptures open . . .”

[1633]  The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[1634]  The first four signs are interpreted as the winds spreading the clouds, carrying them, moving them and distributing them.

[1635]  Different opinions about the judgment.

[1636]  Literally ‘May the conjecturers be killed’.

[1637]Q    Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham in one of his narrations read it as: “Abraham”.

[1638]  The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

[1639]  The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

 Abu ʻAmr read it as: “And those who attained faith and whom We followed (with) their offspring(s) in faith . . .”

[1646]Q   Nafieʻ, Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . their offspring(s) . . .”

[1647]  During their life on earth.

[1648]  Fear of falling into sin.

[1649]Q   Nafieʻ, Al-Kesa’i and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . to Him, for He is . . .”

[1650]  Some pagans claimed that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a poet who authored the Qur’an.

[1651]Q   Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “. . . until they encounter their . . .”

[1652]  Referring to Angel Gabriel.

[1653]Q   Hisham and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “The burning heart did not disbelieve what it saw.”

[1654]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i, Khalaf and Yaʻqub read it as: “Will youpl discredit him despite what he sees?”

[1655]  The Lote-tree of the Extremity is a spot above the seven firmaments; none has ever crossed it, and it is where Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) saw Angel Gabriel in the heavens at the night of his ascendance (Mi’raj).

[1656]  Al-Lāt, Al-ʻUzza and Manāt were names of three goddesses in Arabia.

[1657]  Though pagan Arabs considered having daughters to be shameful, they attributed it to God, so the Qur’an is debating them according to their own logic.

[1658]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Those who avoid the grave kind of sin and . . .”

[1659]Q   Though pronounced in Arabic as Ibrahim, Hisham read it as: “Abraham”.

[1660]  The Arabic word, zawjayn, can also mean ‘two kinds’ or ‘two types’.

[1661]  Sirius was a star worshiped by pagan Arabs.

[1662]  The pagan tribe of Prophet Hûd.

[1663]  The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

[1664]  Comparing their injustices and atrocities to those of the people of Quraysh, the tribe of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

[1665]  Where the people of Prophet Lot lived.

[1666]Q   Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “And every settled matter (has drawn near).”

[1667]Q   Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “So We widely opened the . . .”

[1670]  The pagan tribe of Prophet Salih.

[1672]  The water is to be shared between them and the she-camel.

[1673] The Arabic word used is Qur’an which literally means ‘recital’ or ‘recitation’.

[1674]  Prophet Lot.

[1675]  Saqar is one of the names which the Qur’an gave to the fire of Hell.

[1676]  The Arabic word used is najm which also means ‘star’; notice the suitability of the term which connects what is before it with what is after it.

[1677]Q   Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “. . . palm trees. 12 And (He created) grains in the blades, and (he created) fragrant plants.”

 Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “. . . and (grains of) fragrant plants.”

[1678]  The Qur’an is addressing the two types of responsible creatures: humans and jinn.

[1679]  The Arabic word used is jānn (the singular of jinn), which is an unseen being that is accountable for its actions.

[1680]  Either the fresh water of rivers and the salty water of seas, or the waters of two different oceans.

[1683]  The Arabic word used is Aʻlām which also means ‘tall mountains’.

[1684]  The earth.

[1685]Q   Hamza, Al-Kesa’i and Yaʻqub read it as: “He will attend to you . . .”

[1686]  The Qur’anic style involves leaving part of the meaning to be deduced by the listener; Ar-Rāzi and other exegetes said that this may mean ‘except with authority from God’, or ‘except with authority that you do not have’.

[1687]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Rouh read it as: “Flares of fire and (of) brass . . .”

[1692]  The Arabic word used for refreshing is kareem which literally means ‘noble’.

[1695]  Trees in Hell which produce hot, bitter, rotten fruit.

[1725]Q   All except ʻAsem read it as: “. . . in the assembly.”

[1726]  The Qur’an always uses verb ‘to bring’ rather than verb ‘to give’ in association with charity; this should be pondered by the reader.

[1727]  The Arabic word used is zakāt, which denotes purification and growth.

[1728]  They shall be humiliated in the Hereafter.

[1729]  The Jewish tribe of Banu al-Nadir was besieged by the Muslims for trying to assassinate the Prophet (peace be upon him). An arbiter ruled that its members had to leave Madinah; some of them left to Khaybar while the rest left to the Levant.

[1730]  A grammatical shift from past tense to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of past events.

[1731]Q   Abu ʻAmr read it as: “They vigorously wreck their houses . . .”

[1732]Q   Abu Jaʻfar and Hisham read it as: “. . . so that a closed circuit is not created between the wealthy among you.”

[1733]  The Arabic word used is muhajereen, which refers to the Muslims of Makkah who were forced to flee as refugees from their homes to Madinah where they were welcomed.

[1734]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[1735]Q   Ibn Kathir and Abu ʻAmr read it as: “. . . or from behind a wall.”

[1737]  A grammatical shift to present tense, which serves to create a vivid portrait of future events.

[1760]Q   Ibn Kathir and Shuʻba read it as: “. . . committed an evidenced obscenity.”

[1761]  Puberty is a condition for marriage in Islam; some women do not menstruate because of abnormalities of the reproductive tract.

[1762]  The divorced women.

[1763]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah). Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1767]  Addressing two of the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him): the one who disclosed the secret and the one who listened to her.

[1768]  The Qur’an is addressing all the wives of the Prophet (peace be upon him) using the feminine plural pronoun.

[1769]  The Arabic word Muslimāt (feminine and plural form of Muslim) means women who willingly submit to God.

[1770]Q   Shuʻba read it as: “. . . repent to Allah with a repentance of sincerity . . .”

[1771]Q   All except for Hafs, Abu ʻAmr and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . and His Scripture and was . . .”

[1772]  The Arabic word dunya translated here as ‘lowest’ is the same word used to describe the life of this world as the ‘Earlier’ Life, as it carries both meanings: lowest and earlier.

[1773]  Frequently the Qur’an addresses the events of the Hereafter in past tense; this grammatical shift should be pondered by the reader.

[1774]  A grammatical shift from 3rd person to 1st person.

[1775]Q   Yaʻqub read it as: “‘This is what youpl used to (challengingly) call for.’”

[1776]Q   Al-Kesa’i read it as: “. . . and soon they will know who is . . .”

[1777]Q   All except for Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ‘Amr, Hafs, Al-Kesa’i and Khalaf read it as: “Is it true that because he has money and sons, 15 when Our signs are recited to him, he says, ‘Legends of the ancients!’?”

[1778]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Quran, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1779]  The Arabic word used is Muslimeen which means those who willingly submit to God, regardless of which prophet they followed.

[1780]  A metaphor meaning ‘when matters become dire’; it refers to the Day of Judgment.

[1781]  This verse refers to the disbelievers.

[1784]  Literally ‘scripture’.

[1785]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[1786]  The Qur’an.

[1787]Q   Ibn Kathir, Yaʻqub, Hisham and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “. . . little do they believe, 42 nor is it the speech of a soothsayer—little do they remember.”

[1788]Q   Nafieʻ, Abu ‘Amr, Shuʻba, Abu Jaʻfar and Ibn Zekwan in one of his narrations read it as: “. . . little do you remember.”

[1789]  Literally ‘by the right arm’, which is a metaphor for strength.

[1790]Q   Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “A flood has flooded with a punishment sure to come . . .” According to the dialect of the tribes of Hijaz, the narration of Nafieʻ, Ibn ʻAmer and Abu Jaʻfar means exactly the same as all the others.

[1791]  Abu Jaʻfar and Al-Bazzi in one of his narrations read it as: “. . . and no intimate (friend) is asked (about) his intimate (friend) . . .”

[1793]Q   All except for Hafs read it as: “. . . It is a raging fire. 16 It strips away the scalps . . .”

[1794]  This may mean ‘turned away from the truth’.

[1795]  A grammatical shift from singular to plural.

[1796]  A metaphor for maintaining chastity.

[1823] The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah). Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the

unit of text in the Qur’an, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a

sign from God.

[1836]Q   Ibn Kathir and Shuʻba read it as: “Upon them are garments of green silk, and (upon them is) brocade . . .”

Abu ʻAmr, Ibn ʻAmer, Abu Jaʻfar and Yaʻqub read it as: “. . . green garments of silk and of brocade . . .”

Nafei’ read it as Hafs, while all the rest read it as: “. . . them are garments of green silk and of brocade . . .”

[1839]  Referring to the disbelievers.

[1840]Q   Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Ibn ʻAmer read it as: “Yet they cannot will . . .”

[1841]  According to Al-Qurtubi, exegetes differed about whether this refers to winds or angels.

[1842]  According to Al-Qurtubi, the majority of exegetes mentioned that this refers to the winds.

[1843]  According to Al-Qurtubi, the majority of exegetes mentioned that this refers to the angels.

[1849]Q   Ibn ʻAmer, ʻAsem and Yaʻqub read it as: “a measured gift, 37 (from) the Lord of the heavens and the earth and everything between them, (from) the All-Merciful.”

 Nafieʻ, Ibn Kathir, Abu ʻAmr and Abu Jaʻfar read it as: “a measured gift. 37 (He is) the Lord of the heavens and the earth and everything between them, the All-Merciful.”

 All others read it as: “a measured gift, 37 (from) the Lord of the heavens and the earth and everything between them. (He is) the All-Merciful.”

[1866]  Literally ‘scripture’.

[1867]  Sijjeen is derived from the word ‘sijn’ which means ‘prison’. Here, Allah is expressing the gravity of the matter and describing it as an eternal prison and a painful torment.

[1868]  The Arabic word used is ayat (singular ayah).  Ayah means ‘sign’ or ‘proof’. It is also used to denote the unit of text in the Quran, like ‘verse’ in poetry or ‘sentence’ in prose. Each such unit is considered a ‘sign’ from God.

[1869]  Elliyyeen (Elliyyoon) is derived from the word ‘uluw which means highness. 

[1870]  Elliyyeen (Elliyyoon) is derived from the word ‘uluw which means highness.

[1919]  The Arabic word used is ummuhu which literally means ‘his mother’. According to Al-Qurtubi, Hell was described as a mother because the disbeliever heads towards it like a baby heads towards its mother.

[1924]  The Arabic word used is ma’oun; it denotes small acts of help like lending house utensils, the withholding of which is a sign of stinginess.

[1925]  The Arabic word used is Al Kawthar, which is also the name of a river in Paradise.
